Award.AwardTitle: Flavobacterium Gliding Motility:From protein secretion to cell surface movements

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Gliding motility is a form of movement by which certain bacteria commonly found both inside and on the surface of the body are able to move themselves over solid surfaces. Gliding motility relies on an apparatus composed of unique proteins and this project will explore two fundamental cellular processes (protein secretion and cell movement) and the interactions between them that underlie gliding motility. Graduate and undergraduate students as well as postdoctoral fellows will be actively engaged in the project, and will gain experience in interdisciplinary research involving genetics, molecular biology, and microscopic and mathematical modeling. They will also receive training in scientific writing and presentation. Results of the project will be reported by students at national meetings and published in the scientific literature, and genetic tools that are developed will be made available to the scientific community. Results of this research will be incorporated into undergraduate laboratory exercises and public lectures will be presented to convey the excitement of scientific discovery.

The research will address 3 specific aims related to the functioning of the type IX secretion system (T9SS) responsible for delivering surface adhesin SprB which is responsible for the gliding motility apparatus. The goals are: (1) to characterize using biochemical and genetic approaches the mechanism by which secreted proteins are targeted to the T9SS; (2) to define the moving components of the motility machinery by fusing fluorescent proteins to components of the motility apparatus to identify those that move rapidly over long distances (mathematical analyses of these movements will be used to construct models to explain gliding); and (3) to distinguish between the T9SS and the gliding motility apparatus to determine which proteins function primarily in secretion, in motility, or in both processes. This will help determine if the T9SS and the gliding motility apparatus are two independent machines or different aspects of a single machine. Cells with mutations in T9SS genes will be examined to determine if they retain gliding motor function. Mutations that result in defects in either motility or secretion, but not both, will be isolated and analyzed to determine which proteins function primarily in secretion and which function in motility. Comparative analysis of the F. johnsoniae and Cellulophaga algicola T9SSs and their respective gliding machines will identify conserved features and highlight the roles of individual proteins in secretion or motility. The bacteria studied belong to the understudied phylum, Bacteroidetes. Bacteriodetes is one of the largest bacterial phyla where the proteins that make up the T9SS and the gliding motility apparatus are common. However, these proteins are not found in other groups of bacteria. A more complete understanding of the T9SS and the gliding machinery will expand our understanding of mechanisms of bacterial protein secretion, dynamic protein movements within cells, and cell movements over surfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research explored two fundamental cellular processes: cell movement and protein secretion. It elucidated the functioning of the novel gliding motility and protein secretion machines of the bacterium Flavobacterium johnsoniae. F. johnsoniae and many related bacteria in the phylum Bacteroidetes crawl over surfaces by gliding motility. They rely on a novel motility apparatus composed of proteins that are unique to this large and diverse group of bacteria. Gld and Spr proteins comprise the motility machinery. Cell movement occurs when the large adhesive cell surface protein SprB is propelled rapidly along the cell length by motors (made of Gld proteins) embedded in the cell envelope. SprB thus functions somewhat like a tank tread to move the cell. SprB is delivered to the cell-surface by the novel type IX secretion system (T9SS) that is intertwined with the motility machinery. This research expanded our understanding of gliding motility, the T9SS, and the relationship between these.

The motility adhesin SprB was studied to understand motility and secretion. SprB was dissected and tagged with the fluorescent protein GFP to monitor its secretion and movement along the cell surface during gliding. Attachment of small portions of the amino and carboxy terminal ends of SprB to GFP resulted in secretion of GFP across the cell envelope, attachment to the motility apparatus on the cell surface, and rapid movement along the cell surface by the motility machinery. The large central portion of SprB was apparently needed to interact with the surface and function as an adhesive 'tread', resulting in cell movement. Components of the secretion machinery were identified that specifically facilitate secretion of SprB.

Genetic experiments were used to untangle the T9SS from the gliding motility apparatus. Mutations that disrupted either motility or secretion but not both were isolated and analyzed to determine which proteins function primarily in secretion, which function in motility, and which function in both processes. This allowed us to begin to separate the two outputs of the T9SS motor: secretion and cell movement. Comparative analysis of the gliding and secretion machines of diverse bacteria within the phylum Bacteroidetes identified conserved features and highlighted the roles of individual proteins in motility and secretion. The Bacteroidetes T9SS and gliding machineries are not closely related to other secretion or motility systems. The T9SS efficiently secretes many different proteins, some of which are very large. This research expanded our understanding of mechanisms of bacterial protein secretion, dynamic protein movements within cells, and cell movements over surfaces.

T9SSs are not just of academic interest, they also have practical importance. We demonstrated that the T9SS secretes enzymes needed to digest cellulose and other difficult to digest polysaccharides. The novel cellulose digestion mechanisms that we revealed may in the future be used to efficiently convert this renewable resource into liquid biofuels or other products. Our results also suggest that T9SSs secrete virulence factors to cause disease. We demonstrated that the T9SSs of flavobacterium fish pathogens are required for their ability to cause disease. Flavobacteria are among the most important freshwater aquaculture pathogens. They impede the development of sustainable aquaculture, which is needed to feed our growing population. Our studies begin to explain how these bacteria cause disease, and they suggest control measures. Since related bacteria cause disease in other animals and in people, these studies have broad impact.

Members of the phylum Bacteroidetes are important in many environments, including the human body, but they are understudied. We developed genetic tools for these bacteria to explore protein secretion and motility and we made these tools freely available to others. They were recently used by multiple labs to reveal surprising aspects of Bacteroidetes protein synthesis, respiration, polysaccharide digestion, harvesting of energy from sunlight, plant growth promotion, CRISPR gene editing systems, and production of bioactive molecules as possible therapeutics.

Undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral scientists conducted most of the research on gliding and the T9SS. They were trained in molecular, genetic, and microscopic approaches, in the ethical conduct of research, and in presentation and scientific writing. They presented their findings at major scientific meetings and published them in leading scientific journals. Research on F. johnsoniae was incorporated into undergraduate laboratory courses and public lectures to convey the excitement and the practical benefits of scientific discovery to a broader audience.
